pageProps.contentHtml:
weak convergence

If XXX is a compact metric space, we denote by P(X)\mathcal{P}\p{X}P(X) the set of positive BOrel measures μ\muμ on XXX with μ(X)=1\mu\p{X} = 1μ(X)=1.

  1. Let φ ⁣:X→[0,∞]\func{\phi}{X}{\br{0,\infty}}φ:X→[0,∞] be a lower-semicontinuous function on a compact metric space XXX. Show that if μ\muμ and μn\mu_nμn​ for n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N are in P(X)\mathcal{P}\p{X}P(X) and μn→μ\mu_n \to \muμn​→μ with respect to the weak-star topology on P(X)\mathcal{P}\p{X}P(X), then

    ∫φ dμ≤lim inf⁡n→∞∫φ dμn.\int \phi \,\diff\mu \leq \liminf_{n\to\infty} \int \phi \,\diff\mu_n.∫φdμ≤n→∞liminf​∫φdμn​.

  2. Let K⊆RdK \subseteq \R^dK⊆Rd be a compact set. For μ∈P(K)\mu \in \mathcal{P}\p{K}μ∈P(K), we define

    E(μ)=∫K∫K1∣x−y∣ dμ(x) dμ(y).E\p{\mu} = \int_K \int_K \frac{1}{\abs{x - y}} \,\diff\mu\p{x} \,\diff\mu\p{y}.E(μ)=∫K​∫K​∣x−y∣1​dμ(x)dμ(y).

    Here ∣z∣\abs{z}∣z∣ denotes the Euclidean norm of z∈Rdz \in \R^dz∈Rd.

    Show that the function E ⁣:P(K)→[0,∞]\func{E}{\mathcal{P}\p{K}}{\br{0,\infty}}E:P(K)→[0,∞] attains its minimum on P(K)\mathcal{P}\p{K}P(K) (which could possibly be ∞\infty∞).
Solution.

  1. Since φ\phiφ is lower-semicontinuous, there exists a sequence {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ of continuous functions on XXX which increase pointwise to φ\phiφ, and so we have

    ∫fk dμn≤∫φ dμn  ⟹  lim inf⁡n→∞∫fk dμn≤lim inf⁡n→∞∫φ dμn.\int f_k \,\diff\mu_n \leq \int \phi \,\diff\mu_n \implies \liminf_{n\to\infty} \int f_k \,\diff\mu_n \leq \liminf_{n\to\infty} \int \phi \,\diff\mu_n.∫fk​dμn​≤∫φdμn​⟹n→∞liminf​∫fk​dμn​≤n→∞liminf​∫φdμn​.

    for all n,k∈Nn, k \in \Nn,k∈N. By Riesz representation, (C(X))∗\p{C\p{X}}^*(C(X))∗ is the space of positive Borel measures on XXX. Hence, weak-* convergence of {μn}n\set{\mu_n}_n{μn​}n​ means

    lim inf⁡n→∞∫fk dμn=∫fk dμ,\liminf_{n\to\infty} \int f_k \,\diff\mu_n = \int f_k \,\diff\mu,n→∞liminf​∫fk​dμn​=∫fk​dμ,

    since each fkf_kfk​ is continuous. Since the fkf_kfk​ are increasing, this means that f1≤fkf_1 \leq f_kf1​≤fk​, and because XXX is compact, f1f_1f1​ is bounded. Hence, the fkf_kfk​ are bounded uniformly from below, so we may apply monotone convergence to get

    lim⁡k→∞∫fk dμ=∫φ dμ.\lim_{k\to\infty} \int f_k \,\diff\mu = \int \phi \,\diff\mu.k→∞lim​∫fk​dμ=∫φdμ.

    Hence,

    ∫φ dμ≤lim inf⁡n→∞∫φ dμn.\int \phi \,\diff\mu \leq \liminf_{n\to\infty} \int \phi \,\diff\mu_n.∫φdμ≤n→∞liminf​∫φdμn​.

  2. Let I=inf⁡P(K)EI = \inf_{\mathcal{P}\p{K}} EI=infP(K)​E. If I=∞I = \inftyI=∞, then any measure on P(K)\mathcal{P}\p{K}P(K) is a minimizer, e.g., a normalized Lebesgue measure will work. Otherwise, let {μn}n⊆P(K)\set{\mu_n}_n \subseteq \mathcal{P}\p{K}{μn​}n​⊆P(K) be a sequence such that E(μn)→IE\p{\mu_n} \to IE(μn​)→I as n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞. By Banach-Alaoglu (the μn\mu_nμn​ all hae norm 111), there exists a measure μ∈P(K)\mu \in \mathcal{P}\p{K}μ∈P(K) such that, passing to a subsequence if necessary, μn→μ\mu_n \to \muμn​→μ weakly-*.

    We claim that μn⊗μn→μ⊗μ\mu_n \otimes \mu_n \to \mu \otimes \muμn​⊗μn​→μ⊗μ weakly-* in (C(K×K))∗\p{C\p{K \times K}}^*(C(K×K))∗ as well. Indeed, by Stone-Weierstrass, the set

    A={∑k=1nckfk(x)gk(x) | n∈N, ck∈R, fk,gk∈C(K)}A = \set{\sum_{k=1}^n c_kf_k\p{x}g_k\p{x} \st n \in \N,\ c_k \in \R,\ f_k, g_k \in C\p{K}}A={k=1∑n​ck​fk​(x)gk​(x)∣∣​n∈N, ck​∈R, fk​,gk​∈C(K)}

    is uniformly dense in C(K×K)C\p{K \times K}C(K×K). Moreover,

    lim⁡n→∞∫K∫K∑k=1Nckfk(x)gk(y) dμn(x) dμn(y)=lim⁡n→∞∑k=1Nck(∫Kfk(x) dμn(x))(∫Kgk(y) dμn(y))=∑k=1N∑k=1Nck(∫Kfk(x) dμ(x))(∫Kgk(y) dμ(y))=∫K∫K∑k=1Nckfk(x)gk(y) dμ(x) dμ(y),\begin{aligned} \lim_{n\to\infty} \int_K \int_K \sum_{k=1}^N c_k f_k\p{x} g_k\p{y} \,\diff\mu_n\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y} &= \lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{k=1}^N c_k \p{\int_K f_k\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{x}} \p{\int_K g_k\p{y} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y}} \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^N \sum_{k=1}^N c_k \p{\int_K f_k\p{x} \,\diff\mu\p{x}} \p{\int_K g_k\p{y} \,\diff\mu\p{y}} \\ &= \int_K \int_K \sum_{k=1}^N c_k f_k\p{x} g_k\p{y} \,\diff\mu\p{x} \,\diff\mu\p{y}, \end{aligned}n→∞lim​∫K​∫K​k=1∑N​ck​fk​(x)gk​(y)dμn​(x)dμn​(y)​=n→∞lim​k=1∑N​ck​(∫K​fk​(x)dμn​(x))(∫K​gk​(y)dμn​(y))=k=1∑N​k=1∑N​ck​(∫K​fk​(x)dμ(x))(∫K​gk​(y)dμ(y))=∫K​∫K​k=1∑N​ck​fk​(x)gk​(y)dμ(x)dμ(y),​

    so μn⊗μn→μ⊗μ\mu_n \otimes \mu_n \to \mu \otimes \muμn​⊗μn​→μ⊗μ on a dense set, hence on all of C(K×K)C\p{K \times K}C(K×K). Finally, observe that 1∣x−y∣\frac{1}{\abs{x - y}}∣x−y∣1​ is a lower-semicontinuous function on K×KK \times KK×K: if x≠yx \neq yx=y, then it is continuous there, and otherwise, if x=yx = yx=y, then the function tends to ∞\infty∞ when approaching these points. Thus, by (1),

    E(μ)=∫K∫K1∣x−y∣ dμ(x) dμ(y)≤lim inf⁡n→∞∫K∫K1∣x−y∣ dμn(x) dμn(y)=lim inf⁡n→∞E(μn)=I,\begin{aligned} E\p{\mu} &= \int_K \int_K \frac{1}{\abs{x - y}} \,\diff\mu\p{x} \,\diff\mu\p{y} \\ &\leq \liminf_{n\to\infty} \int_K \int_K \frac{1}{\abs{x - y}} \,\diff\mu_n\p{x} \,\diff\mu_n\p{y} \\ &= \liminf_{n\to\infty} E\p{\mu_n} \\ &= I, \end{aligned}E(μ)​=∫K​∫K​∣x−y∣1​dμ(x)dμ(y)≤n→∞liminf​∫K​∫K​∣x−y∣1​dμn​(x)dμn​(y)=n→∞liminf​E(μn​)=I,​

    so μ\muμ is a minimizer.
